newsitem.title: UK: UK watchdog dismisses 'parody' beer ads complaint.
newsitem.headline: UK watchdog dismisses 'parody' beer ads complaint.

text.p: The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) said on Wednesday it had dismissed a complaint about two advertisements for Michelob lager which parodied religious-style messages to promote the beer.

The ASA, Britain's advertising watchdog, said it had received a complaint from a consumer who objected that U.S. drinks giant, Anheuser-Busch's advertising -- using the slogan 'The Gospel according to St. Louis' -- mocked genuine religious messages and was offensive to people who "drew comfort from them".

One ad showed trees and footsteps in the snow and claimed 'May I always have a Michelob for those I meet along my path'. The other, a postcard insert, said 'The secret of happiness is to give Michelob to others' and displayed a picture of flowers.

The advertiser told the ASA that its research showed that its target audience, who tended not to have "deeply religious views", would not be offended by the publicity material. It was meant to be humorous, Anheuser-Busch European Trade Ltd said.
The ASA agreed the ads were unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence to readers.

The ruling came after Anheuser-Busch was attacked last month by American Indian advocacy groups for a British commercial which showed an American Indian drinking Budweiser lager -- an image, they said, which was insensitive to the alcoholism problem facing large numbers of American Indians.
